awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Using Remote Sensing and Geospatial Data for Informed Climate Adaptation, Mitigation, Resiliency, and Environmentally Friendly Solutions
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of advancements in geophysics and engineering using environmental and geospatial solutions by utilizing models based on remote sensing and other spatial data. This project may impact areas such as urban sustainability, water quality and quantity monitoring, and risk analyses based on natural and climate change. Nowadays, with significant satellite remote sensing observations availability and advances in machine learning and cloud computing, new analyses could inform various stakeholders and policy makers. Satellite data are advantageous because of their spatial (from local up to global scale) and temporal coverage (some from decades ago) which could significantly lower the costs of alternative, ground-based, data collection and processing. Particular topics such as water quality monitoring (including Harmful Algal Bloom (HAB) detection) and identifying a resilient solution for pedestrians during heatwaves using satellite data are among the technology and services to be explored in this project.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of high spatial and temporal resolution satellite data products using data processing, machine learning, and validation efforts. The project defines the existing gaps that could be filled with remote sensing and data processing technologies such as: algorithms to statistically develop a high spatio-temporal resolution downscaled satellite data; models to identify cool corridors and open street paths as a resilient solution and response to urban heat islands (UHIs) which will mitigate the adverse health impacts of UHIs; and algorithms for small water-bodies and lakes water quality monitoring using fine resolution satellite imageries.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

Our project focused on advancing water quality monitoring through the application of remote sensing technology, specifically targeting small lakes that often lack sufficient monitoring resources. This work addressed both the intellectual merit and broader impacts outlined in NSF’s merit review criteria, with promising findings that could make a lasting contribution to environmental management.

Intellectual Merit

Throughout the project, we participated in the national I-Corps program, which enabled us to conduct over 120 customer discovery interviews with professionals and stakeholders in water quality monitoring, including representatives from federal, state, and local agencies. We also engaged over 30 environmental specialists and limnologists from private companies. These interviews provided deep insights into current challenges and highlighted the potential for remote sensing to fill gaps in water quality monitoring for small lakes. Traditionally, remote sensing applications have been confined to research environments. Our findings suggest that these technologies can be scaled and adapted for real-world, routine monitoring, helping make lake health assessments more accessible and cost-effective.

Broader Impacts

Our project holds societal benefits that extend beyond scientific discovery. By democratizing access to water quality data, particularly for underserved communities, we empower local governments and community groups to take a proactive role in environmental stewardship. Healthier lakes support public health, recreational activities, and local economies dependent on tourism, fishing, and agriculture. During our participation in the Global Lakes Ecological Observatory Network (GLEON) meeting in Poland, we also discovered that our remote sensing technology has potential applications in riverine environments, broadening its relevance and impact.

Professional Development

The I-Corps program provided our team—comprising an entrepreneurial lead, co-technical leads, and an industry expert lead—with invaluable professional development opportunities. Through customer discovery and market analysis exercises, the team gained skills in assessing market needs and articulating the value of our technology effectively. These experiences not only enhanced our technical capabilities but also equipped us with communication and commercialization skills that will benefit future projects.

Conclusion

Overall, this project has set the groundwork for broader adoption of remote sensing technologies in environmental monitoring. By moving these tools from research labs into practical use, we are opening new avenues for cost-effective, scalable solutions in water quality assessment. This work contributes to both the fields of environmental monitoring and geospatial data analysis, paving the way for a more sustainable approach to ecosystem health monitoring.
